meta_data.title: What's Your Mourning Routine?
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 4:1-3 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast where we do fast, fun, free, daily deep dives into books of the Bible. And right now, we're going to restor. I would like to start today by telling you about my morning routine. No, not my M-O-R-N-I-N-G morning routine. I mean my M-O-U-R-N-I-N-G morning routine when I'm sad about something. Whether it's something that was my own dang fault or no fault of my own that I'm just sad about, I find that there are two things that normally happen. One, I tend to find somewhere to sit where I can just stare off into the distance and let my eyes water a little bit and just let time kind of fade away while I'm just sad and the sadness or regret wash over me. Two, speaking of washing over me, I will then at some point take a shower and I'll have one good morning shower, M-O-U-R-N-I-N-G, where I will just put that hot water right on the back of my head and I will let it run over my nose and I will just stare down the drain and think about the sadness going down the drain. And then sometime after that, I always end up feeling better. Back in the day, they used sackcloth and ashes. That's what they would do when they were sad about things, whether something happened to them or something that was their own dang fault. They'd wear real scratchy, uncomfortable clothes and they'd put filthy, dirty, black, cold char on their face to make it really clear to everybody. I'm sad and I'm sad for a really good reason. This was a practice that goes way beyond the boundaries of the Bible, but we certainly see it happen a lot in the Bible as well. That cloth and ashes is just a metaphor for deep, deep mourning. By the time we get to the New Testament, we see that that process of mourning had become a little bit performative, a little bit bastardized. You're starting to see people who are literally getting paid to just wail and shriek and be sad about things. There's even this funny little playful moments with the professional mourner scene when Jesus of Nazareth reverses death when the mourners are already there. It's not in the text, but you can almost imagine them being like, do we still get paid? Because we still mourned and the person was dead for a little while. We need to add a writer to our contract in the future when we do this. But when it comes up in the Old Testament, it's usually presented as a very authentic expression of an outward physical manifestation of deep inner turmoil. And now that the big edict of Esther chapter three has gone through, I mean, a farce of a legislative process has occurred. And without anybody really thinking about it or debating it and without there being anybody to argue the other side, I mean, we shouldn't commit genocide for no reason whatsoever just because that one guy said to. Nope, none of that happened. The edict has been issued. It's the real deal. The king has put his name and his reputation and indeed the reputation of the throne, the credibility of the empire is on the line. And it seems like he doesn't even know it or get what he just did. Because at the end of Esther chapter three, he's great. He's sitting down getting a drink with his genocide buddy. But all of the capital is bewildered because the edict makes no sense. It doesn't fit with the whole cut of the jib of Persia. It doesn't fit with the spoken values. It doesn't strategically make any sense. If you'll do this to one people group and make us participate and just let everybody plunder them, why wouldn't you do it to everybody else? So by the end of chapter three, we've got the emotional reaction of the king and Haman, but whatever, let me kick. Let's have a drink. We've got the reaction of the non-Jewish citizenry of Persia who are bewildered by this, but there's one glaring reaction we're still missing. And that's the one from the people who are going to be on the receiving end of this horrible thing. Mordecai and the Jews, how are they going to mourn? Are they just going to stare off into the distance and be misty-eyed like me? Are they going to do the sackcloth, the nashes thing? I'm just going to spoil it for you. It's the sackcloth and ashes. Esther chapter four, verse one, when Mordecai learned of all that had been done, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes and went out into the city wailing loudly and bitterly. What he went, only as far as the king's gate because no one clothed in sackcloth was allowed to enter it. In every province to which the edict and order of the king came, there was great mourning among the Jews with fasting, weeping and wailing, many lay in sackcloth and ashes. This is another one of those passage where the Bible is stunningly understated, but also I get it. I don't understand really what the advantage here would be of lingering for another paragraph or two to be like, they were really sad. If you think about what we just said in the couple of sentences there at the beginning of chapter four about how sad they were, now here's two more paragraphs to just reiterate that very, very heavily. They're super-note, just as a reader, you're supposed to be able to do the math on it, but it'd be weird if we skipped this emotional beat and didn't see the reaction of the people who are going to be on the receiving end of this thing and predictably, they're broken up about it. There's a little hint here though that is one of the places that comes the closest to acknowledging God in the text. I mean, God again does not get mentioned formally in the book of Esther, but it says many of the Jews, they were mourning with fasting, weeping and wailing. Well, I suppose anybody could weep and wail, but the fasting, what's that about? Maybe it's to lose weight or just clear their minds so they will be better ready when this day arrives, but probably that fasting was an act of dedication or partnered with prayer as an appeal to the Lord. We know that this fasting and prayer routine is something that other exiles had done during the earlier Babylonian captivity would make sense that, you know, hearkening back to those moments of dire persecution that Daniel and Shadrach and Meshach and Abednego went through as recorded in the book of Daniel under the reign of the Babylonians. You know, it makes sense. There's kind of a template here when there's a horrible oppressive persecutory threat going on. So it's at least an acknowledgement that the Jewish people in the book of Esther are thinking of God or appealing to God that I think we can see there. But I'm really intrigued by Mordecai's morning. It reminds me of a scene in HBO's Rome, which is a show I don't recommend you watch, as is the case with all shows. But it's one that I went and watched for you so that I could tell you it was bad many years ago. And in that show, there's a rivalry between a couple of women, one of them from Julius Caesar's family, one of them from another family and one of them finally. As her weasily dirty nonsense and she gets a leg up on the other lady and commits a grievous injustice against her. And I will never forget the scene of, I don't remember the characters, the lady from the Julie I family standing in sack cloth and ashes, hair all tattered. She's a very refined woman. She's nobility. But in this scene, she's totally broken. And she stands outside the house of Atia of the Juniye demanding justice just again and again, like making it clear to everybody in high society Rome that there's a grievance here and I'm not leaving until it was addressed. And I got to think there's an element to that with what's going on with Mordecai here. I mean, obviously he's very, very sad. I suppose tomorrow we can maybe talk about all of the elements that we compose that morning for him. But I think there's also something very strategic here. He's making it clear that a horrible injustice is taking place, that he has a horrible grievance to be adjudicated. He wants people to know this is part of his plan for trying to respond to what's happened and make things better. He's not allowed to go inside the king's gate. What is that about? Maybe because sat cloth and ash was a bit of a form of protest for justice or a plea for justice. And inside the king's gate is where rational discourse and debate about justice occurs. Maybe, maybe politically, maybe, judicially, they just didn't want that kind of performative grieving and demand for justice in the halls of sober blind justice. I don't know, I'm just speculating there. I have no idea, but it wasn't allowed. So instead Mordecai is back to doing what he's been doing in the past. He hangs out in the streets. He is down with the hubbub and the buzz and he knows what's going on. Good things have happened in the past when Mordecai lingered around the gates, the reader who was attentive to the rhythms and rhymes of this story. Hopefully he hears like, man, he's really sad. But the last time he was at the gate. There was a thwarting of a plan to kill. Maybe somehow this is the beginnings of the thwarting of another plan to kill. I don't want to dismiss this little nod to the grieving, the very public grieving of Mordecai and the Jews as being somehow performative or entirely designed to win sympathy. I think there's just a genuine heart brokenness over the way that this has gone down. And we can talk about that more tomorrow. A little bit of housekeeping here on the way out the door. Several of you have been kind enough to support this program. Many of you through planning center, but even more of you through patreon.com slash the TMBH podcast. And over there on Patreon, we had a problem here over the last couple of weeks. Well, we didn't really have a problem. Patreon had a bad couple of weeks. And I've heard from several of you that you were trying to support the program, but your card wasn't being recognized and they weren't charging your cards properly. I looked into it and then a big mass email from Patreon went out to everybody, all the content creators who work with them and said, yeah, sure enough, you've probably heard about this. We are having problems and we think we've got it straightened out and it's good to go. But it would be wise to let everybody know who supports that it might be good to go and just double check and make sure things are right. I did notice a shocking hit over there as a result of their issues. So hey, if you're supporting the program through patreon and you have a minute to go and double check and just make sure that things are right on that account, that would be awesome. If not, I always feel weird bringing it up. So whatever's cool. Thank you so much to everybody who is supporting in any way has supported in any way might someday in any way or might not in any way. I'm just so damn grateful that we get to do this. And thank you in advance for considering double checking on that. If you are part of the Patreon thing. Okay, that is it tomorrow. We're going to talk about the specific five or seven reasons I've thought of for why Mordecai is particularly heartbroken about this thing that go beyond the obvious. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
